author: .vbuterin
content: Is SETCODE useful when pretty much every wallet will have to be a delegatecall forwarder anyway for gas savings reasons?

author: .vbuterin
content: (btw, I wonder if at some point we should just enshrine delegatecall forwarding; like, give each address a "my code lives here" address, and an opcode to change it)

author: _shemnon
content:
Would a "precompile" serve that better?  Create a canonical EVM bytecode then clients can identify the codehash and optimize the dispatch?  

But this illustrates the complexities of forwarders: who has the authority to update the target address?  The EOA of the address (in context of EIP-7377)?  An EOA set at deploy time? Any contract? Can that updater be updated?  and if so by who?  Which starts the whole loop over again (who can update the updater updater) and we have to settle on a base case.

One and done enshrinement (like 7377 does for EOAs) is easier to assess for security, but standards and practices for who can update smart contracts will continually evolve, so I feel leaving it in the EVM layer is ultimately safer than enshrining one practice in the protocol layer.
